author: By Katie Rogers and Brad Plumer
title: Biden Administration Moves to Fix Supply Chain Bottlenecks
description: A swath of recommendations calls for more investments, new supply chains and less reliance on other countries for crucial goods.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Tuesday outlined a swath of actions and recommendations meant to address supply chain disruptions caused by the coronavirus pandemic and decrease reliance on other countries for crucial goods by increasing domestic production capacity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wille
title: The Grindr Advice Column That Became a Memoir of Modern Queer Life
description: In “Hola Papi,” the writer John Paul Brammer mines his own experiences and traumas to deliver wisdom for queer readers.
content: HOLA PAPIHow to Come Out in a Walmart Parking Lot and Other Life LessonsBy John Paul Brammer
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Dear Senthuran: A Black Spirit Memoir,’ by Akwaeke Emezi: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Dear Senthuran: A Black Spirit Memoir,” by Akwaeke Emezi
content: I need to tell you about a turning point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Nectar Collectors
description: Christopher Adams’s puzzle reminds me of someone.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It’s not often that a crossword that is not an actual tribute puzzle evokes the memory of a celebrity for me, but this one by Christopher Adams did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A Curfew and Clashes With Police in Washington Square Park
description: The confrontation over a new restriction at the Greenwich Village gathering spot has raised tensions over officers' conduct.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Are We Destined for a Trump Coup in 2024?
description: Some alarm is understandable. The progressive sense of certain doom is not.
content: I wrote my weekend column about three ways that Donald Trump might be prevented from plunging the country into crisis in 2024, should he reproduce both his 2020 defeat and his quest to overturn the outcome: first, through the dramatic electoral overhauls favored by progressives; second, through a Bidenist politics of normalcy that prevents the G.O.P. from capturing the House or Senate; or third, through the actions of Republican officials who keep their heads down and don’t break with Trump but, as in 2020, refuse to go along if he turns another loss into an attempted putsch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia and Bonnie Wertheim
title: Chris Harrison Has Officially Left ‘The Bachelor’
description: The longtime host permanently parted ways with the reality franchise after stepping back in February.
content: Chris Harrison, the longtime host of “The Bachelor,” “The Bachelorette” and “Bachelor in Paradise,” has parted ways with the reality TV franchise after nearly 20 years as its most constant presence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: America Is Driving the Global Economy. When Does That Become a Problem?
description: New trade data suggests the outlook for the U.S. economy will depend in part on the rate of recovery of other nations.
content: The United States, with its aggressive pandemic aid measures and rapid vaccine rollout, is propelling the world economy, acting as a source of demand in all corners of the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Lyon Dance Biennale Begins, Reduced but Unbowed
description: The festival lost some premieres, but gained others, including one by Dimitris Papaioannou, and kept a free project in an old factory.
content: LYON, France — A million euros wiped off the budget. Large-scale shows canceled. And an elaborate parade through the city — an event that had been drawing crowds of around 250,000 people — dramatically rethought. Despite these obstacles, the 19th Lyon Dance Biennale became, on June 1, the first summer festival to open in France, less than two weeks after the country relaxed its Covid-19-related rules — a little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Blackall
title: The Cat Came Back — All the Way From 16th-Century Rome
description: A time-traveling feline helps solve a Renaissance art mystery in “Da Vinci’s Cat,” by Catherine Gilbert Murdock.
content: DA VINCI’S CATWritten by Catherine Gilbert Murdock Illustrated by Paul O. Zelinsky
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: Dormeshia Wins Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award
description: The tap dancer, choreographer and educator will be honored at a virtual gala on June 12.
content: Dormeshia’s surge of midcareer recognition continues. On Tuesday, the performer and choreographer was named as the winner of the 2021 Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award, an honor that comes with an unrestricted cash prize of $25,000. She will be celebrated for her “exceptional vision and achievement” at a virtual gala on June 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: What is Fastly, the company behind the worldwide internet outage?
description: The little-known cloud computing company had a problem that put many popular websites offline on Tuesday.
content: For a company pitching itself as helping improve the reliability and speed of websites, it is hard to imagine a worse turn of events than what Fastly experienced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Stacey Abrams and her group will try to rally young voters of color behind the For the People Act.
description: The effort, called Hot Call Summer, will center on a huge texting campaign, with organizers aiming to reach 10 million voters in key states where Republicans have pushed voting restrictions.
content: Stacey Abrams, the former Georgia Democratic candidate for governor, and the voting organization she leads are beginning a monthlong advocacy campaign to rally young voters of color to support the For the People Act, an expansive federal elections bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Jim Fassel Bridged Giants Eras With a Smile. And, Once, a Rant.
description: The Giants coach called Gentleman Jim was best known for smoothly transitioning the team out of the Bill Parcells era, but one uncharacteristic tirade stood out.
content: It was the day before Thanksgiving in 2000, and Giants Coach Jim Fassel, who looked like a librarian and generally behaved like the winsome air-conditioning salesman he once was, had a wild, restless look in his eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Beth Hoeg, Monica Gandhi and Daniel Johnson
title: We Must Fully Reopen Schools This Fall. Here’s How.
description: A blueprint for the C.D.C. to bring children back to classrooms safely.
content: As American children conclude what will hopefully be the most discombobulated academic year of their lives, it’s clear that school must be different this fall. Thanks to increasing vaccinations and declining rates of Covid-19 infections, children can safely return to classrooms. To facilitate this, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention should release a blueprint for reopening schools that balances the countless benefits of in-person schooling with the lower risks of Covid-19 to children and (mostly vaccinated) teachers and staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Loki,’ on the Light Side of the Marvel Streaming Universe
description: After “WandaVision” and “The Falcon and the Winter Soldier,” the Norse god’s Disney+ series lets some laughter in.
content: Fairly early in “Loki,” the latest superhero side dish Marvel is serving up on Disney+, the deceitful Norse god of the title has a reckoning — a come-to-Stan Lee moment, if you will. He gets a peek into what could be his future (a future we’ve already seen in multiple Marvel films, which allows for the recycling of some pricey intellectual property) and it doesn’t please him. It doesn’t scare him straight, exactly, but it persuades him to cooperate with the good guys and become the wisecracking consultant to a team of heavily armed time cops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Jim Fassel, Who Coached the Giants to the Super Bowl, Dies at 71
description: He predicted that New York would make the playoffs when no one gave them much of a chance. Then they marched to the championship game, only to lose to the Ravens.
content: Jim Fassel, who was a longtime architect of offensive schemes in the pros and collegiate football and reached the pinnacle of his career when he coached the Giants team that reached the 2001 Super Bowl, died on Monday in Las Vegas. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Benjamin Weiser
title: Biden Justice Department Seeks to Defend Trump in Suit Over Rape Denial
description: Donald Trump is facing a defamation lawsuit brought by E. Jean Carroll, who has accused Mr. Trump of raping her.
content: During the presidential campaign, Joseph R. Biden Jr., then the Democratic candidate, slammed his opponent, Donald J. Trump, for a highly unusual legal move: bringing in the Justice Department to represent him in a defamation lawsuit stemming from a decades-old rape allegation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Coleman
title: New York Theater Workshop Plans a Summer Reopening
description: The Off Broadway institution unveiled a “superseason” of performances beginning in August, and continuing through 2022-23.
content: One major Off Broadway institution announced its return to live performances on Tuesday when New York Theater Workshop unveiled its 2021-22 season, which will begin in August and overwhelmingly feature projects by women and people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Knicks’ Tom Thibodeau Wins Coach of the Year Award
description: In a narrow vote, Thibodeau won the award for the second time in his career after taking the franchise to its first playoff appearance since 2013.
content: Tom Thibodeau, the head coach of the Knicks, won his second Coach of the Year Award, the N.B.A. announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Aaron Rodgers Is a No-Show at Packers Camp. Now What?
description: The N.F.L.’s most valuable player did not attend the first day of Green Bay’s mandatory minicamp, raising the stakes in his dispute with the team.
content: Aaron Rodgers has been the starting quarterback and the primary face of the Green Bay Packers for 13 years. But over the past year or so, his cozy link to the team and its city has looked threatened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janice P. Nimura
title: Why ‘Unwell Women’ Have Gone Misdiagnosed for Centuries
description: The British scholar Elinor Cleghorn’s new history traces medicine’s sexism from Hippocrates to today.
content: UNWELL WOMENMisdiagnosis and Myth in a Man-Made WorldBy Elinor Cleghorn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats’ Improbable New F.E.C. Strategy: More Deadlock Than Ever
description: Here is the inside story of how Democrats, after a decade of defeats at the nation’s top campaign watchdog, are trying to enforce election laws in part by losing on purpose in federal court.
content: WASHINGTON — A funny thing keeps happening in federal court. An arm of the government has not been showing up to defend itself against lawsuits. Some judges appear confused, and less than amused, by the unusual absences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Virginia’s Democratic Primary Races: What to Watch For
description: Former Gov. Terry McAuliffe is seeking his old job, and Democrats will square off in races for lieutenant governor and attorney general.
content: WASHINGTON — Virginia Democrats go to the polls on Tuesday to determine their candidates in races ranging from governor to the State House, but the onset of summer isn’t the only reason this year’s primary season has been sleepy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: The F.B.I. arrests a Pennsylvania man who impersonated Trump’s relatives.
description: The Times revealed last year that a 21-year-old delivery driver had posed as Trump family members on Twitter. On Tuesday, he was charged with fraud.
content: Last year, a Pennsylvania man amassed thousands of followers on Twitter by impersonating relatives of former President Donald J. Trump. In November, he even duped Mr. Trump, who messaged the man “LOVE!” while thinking he was writing to one of his sisters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Amid reopenings, Asian-Americans worry about attacks.
content: Even as millions of Americans leap into a mostly normal summer, some residents are holding back — and it’s not because they’re afraid to get sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum
title: The Real Tax Scandal Is What’s Legal
description: The wealthiest Americans live by a different set of rules, lavishly spending money that isn’t taxed as income.
content: Wealthy Americans can save a lot of money by cheating on their federal income taxes, but that’s nothing compared with how much money they’ve been saving by following the rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Debate Over Hacking Ransomware Hackers
description: The recovery of ransom paid by the Colonial Pipeline operator allays some worries about cryptocurrency — but worries others.
content: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had traced and seized much of the ransom that a major U.S. pipeline operator paid to a Russian hacking collective last month. The ransomware attack shut down the Colonial Pipeline for about a week, prompting fuel shortages and price spikes, until the company paid hackers more than $4 million worth of Bitcoin. But federal officials said that a new F.B.I. task force had recaptured most of the Bitcoins by, in essence, hacking the hackers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Fessler
title: Workplace Harassment in the Age of Remote Work
description: When office closures put physical distance between colleagues, many hoped that incidents of harassment would drop. That flame quickly went dark.
content: — Jennifer Brown, a diversity, equity and inclusion expert
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Texas Democrats Begin Voter Registration Push as G.O.P. Eyes Limits
description: With Republicans moving to pass new voting restrictions in the state, Democrats are starting a major statewide registration program focused on racially diverse communities.
content: The Texas Democratic Party and a coalition of allied progressive groups announced a major voter registration program on Tuesday, pledging to focus on registration in racially diverse communities at a time when the Republican-controlled Texas Legislature is vowing to pass a host of new voting restrictions, many of which would disproportionately affect communities of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nelson D. Schwartz
title: From Appetizers to Tuition, Incentives to Job Seekers Grow
description: Employers are finding ways to get applicants in the door, and to retain employees once they’re hired.
content: College subsidies for children and spouses. Free rooms for summer hotel employees and a set of knives for aspiring culinary workers. And appetizers on the house for anyone willing to sit down for a restaurant job interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: $14 Million Settlement for Water Polo Players Who Accused Coach of Abuse
description: In their lawsuit, the plaintiffs said that USA Water Polo did not do enough to protect them from their coach, Bahram Hojreh. He also faces criminal charges.
content: Twelve female water polo players in California who have accused their former coach of sexually abusing them when they were minors have reached a settlement of nearly $14 million in a lawsuit they brought against two organizations they say failed to protect them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Piccoli and Mike Ives
title: Retired New York Police Officer Dies After Brooklyn Shooting
description: The 57-year-old officer appeared to have been shot by accident after a scuffle broke out near a pizzeria in Kensington.
content: A retired New York Police Department officer died on Monday after he was shot in the torso during a confrontation outside a Brooklyn pizzeria, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Edwards
title: A Jamaican-British Gay Man Makes His Own Way, With Musical Accompaniment
description: Paul Mendez’s debut novel, “Rainbow Milk,” traces the legacy of one family’s decision to leave the Caribbean.
content: RAINBOW MILK By Paul Mendez
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Katie Rogers and Jonathan Weisman
title: Civil rights leaders press Manchin for a path forward on voting rights, but he remains unmoved on a broad bill.
description: The virtual meeting came two days after Mr. Manchin unequivocally stated his opposition to the Democrats’ landmark elections bill.
content: Prominent civil rights leaders implored Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia on Tuesday to help find a path forward in Congress for legislation to protect voting rights, making a case to the measure’s most vocal Democratic opponent that enacting it was an existential imperative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Leader Wants a ‘Lovable’ Country. That Doesn’t Mean He’s Making Nice.
description: Xi Jinping’s remarks to top Communist Party leaders suggest Beijing will focus on courting allies rather than easing its rhetoric against the U.S. and Europe.
content: China’s top diplomats have castigated their American counterparts for hypocrisy and condescension. They icily reminded Europeans of the continent’s experience with genocide. They just accused New Zealand, a country that had been careful not to cause offense, of “gross interference” in China’s affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Overwhelmingly Passes Bill to Bolster Competitiveness With China
description: The wide margin of support reflected a sense of urgency among lawmakers in both parties about shoring up the technological and industrial capacity of the United States to counter Beijing.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate overwhelmingly passed legislation on Tuesday that would pour nearly a quarter-trillion dollars over the next five years into scientific research and development to bolster competitiveness against China.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: F.D.A. Approves New Medication for Alzheimer’s
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 8, 2021.
content: “There’s no way to recover the opportunity to understand whether or not the product really works in the post-approval setting.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Senate Confirms First Biden Judges, Beginning Push to Rebalance Courts
description: The votes were the start of an effort by Democrats to confirm liberals and people of color to the federal courts after Donald J. Trump moved aggressively to install conservative white men.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate confirmed President Biden’s first two judicial nominees on Tuesday with modest Republican support, touching off a liberal sprint to fill scores of federal vacancies, aimed at ideologically rebalancing and diversifying the courts after the Trump era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Remote Work’s Last Hurrah: 6 Spots to Make Your Summer Office
description: As workers prepare to return to the office in coming months, here are six towns and cities to consider squeezing in a working vacation or two.
content: Those who’ve been able to work from home over the last year have had to get creative about their workstations, setting up makeshift offices on balconies, couches or even kitchen counters. Some temporarily relocated to new cities and towns from early in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: The Mayor, the Teacher and a Fight Over a ‘Lost Territory’ of France
description: A battle erupted after a high-school teacher said that Islamists had taken over the city of Trappes, a view vigorously countered by the mayor, sharpening a national debate over French identity.
content: TRAPPES, France — It all began when a high-school teacher warned that Islamists had taken over the city. The teacher went on TV, issuing alarms from inside what he called a “lost city” of the French Republic. In Trappes, he said, he feared for his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Rising prices in China.
content: As inflation worries circle the globe, Beijing is moving swiftly to protect its factories and workplaces from rising costs. Some of its anti-inflation tools include subsidies for small businesses to pay for commodities and limits on commodities trading to rein in speculation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Parliament to Vote on New Government on Sunday
description: If lawmakers approve a fragile new coalition government, Israel will be led by someone other than Benjamin Netanyahu for the first time in 12 years.
content: JERUSALEM — The immediate political future of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is set to be decided on Sunday, after the speaker of Israel’s Parliament said that lawmakers would hold a vote of confidence in a new coalition government that afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Animal,’ by Lisa Taddeo: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Animal,” by Lisa Taddeo
content: I drove myself out of New York City where a man shot himself in front of me. He was a gluttonous man and when his blood came out it looked like the blood of a pig. That’s a cruel thing to think, I know. He did it in a restaurant where I was having dinner with another man, another married man. Do you see how this is going? But I wasn’t always that way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marlise Simons and Marc Santora
title: Ratko Mladic Loses Final Appeal in Genocide Conviction
description: The confirmation of the verdict against the Bosnian Serb former commander, convicted in 2017 of crimes against humanity for his role in the Balkan wars, closes a grim chapter in European history.
content: Nearly three decades after the outbreak of war in the Balkans, which saw some of the most shocking atrocities in Europe since the end of World War II, the conviction of the chief military commander of the bloodletting was upheld on Tuesday by an international tribunal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: For Asian Americans Wary of Attacks, Reopening Is Not an Option
description: Facing a wave of animosity, many Asian Americans remain afraid of public places even as the coronavirus pandemic recedes.
content: Millions of Americans may be leaping into a summer of newly unmasked normalcy. But inside Mandy Lin’s apartment in Philadelphia’s Chinatown neighborhood, the lockdown drags on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Job openings hit a record, a Labor Department survey shows.
description: Employers had 9.3 million positions available in April, more than two million more than before the pandemic.
content: Job openings surged to record levels in April, the latest evidence that businesses are struggling to hire workers as the economy reopens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Judd Architecture Office in Marfa Severely Damaged in Fire
description: The artist Donald Judd’s two-story office in Texas was in the final stages of a renovation that was set to finish July 3.
content: When Gary Mitschke, the chief of the Marfa Volunteer Fire Department, arrived at the Judd Foundation offices in Marfa, Texas, shortly after 12:30 a.m. on Friday, smoke at one building “was coming out of anywhere it could escape from,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Nicole Perlroth
title: U.S. Seizes Share of Ransom From Hackers in Colonial Pipeline Attack
description: Investigators traced 75 Bitcoins worth more than $4 million through nearly two dozen cryptocurrency accounts.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said on Monday that it had seized much of the ransom that a major U.S. pipeline operator had paid last month to a Russian hacking collective, turning the tables on the hackers by reaching into a digital wallet to snatch back millions of dollars in cryptocurrency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Foo Fighters Will Play First Concert Back at Madison Square Garden
description: The first full-capacity arena concert in New York since March 2020 will feature rock ’n’ roll — but only for fans who are fully vaccinated — on June 20.
content: For the first time in more than 15 months, Madison Square Garden is gearing up to host a rock ’n’ roll concert without social distancing, masks or capacity caps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Carne Mare, Andrew Carmellini’s Italian Chophouse, Opens
description: Peruvian flavors in East Harlem, Southern Italian in Midtown East, and more restaurant news.
content: This Italian chophouse from Andrew Carmellini is the latest in the collection of high-profile dining rooms on the South Street Seaport district’s renovated Pier 17. It’s on two floors with views of tall ships and done in butterscotch leather, polished wood and brass to give it a nautical feel, with terra cotta on the walls. Mr. Carmellini said he’d been working on the restaurant for more than three years. “Usually you’re rushing to get ready to open up; we were done last year,” he said. Then the pandemic, of course. Central to the menu are 10 assorted steak cuts, including a Wagyu strip loin cured with Gorgonzola to ramp up the umami. Filling out the choices are a Sicilian Caesar salad with mimosa egg; mozzarella sticks dressed with caviar; a finite list of pastas, including lobster spaghetti; roast duck with mustard fruits that’s a homage to Hosteria d’Ivan near Parma, Italy; a whole salt-baked black sea bass wrapped in fig leaves; and a cowboy veal chop done Milanese-style. His chef de cuisine is Brendan Scott. The wine list concentrates on Italy, France and the United States, with a nice bubbly section to pair with raw bar specialties. There will be outdoor seating on the plaza. (Opens Thursday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: In Bill Clinton and James Patterson’s Second Novel, an Ex-President Goes Rogue
description: “The President’s Daughter” is set in motion with a kidnapping, and then a paramilitary operation is put together in response.
content: It is relatively easy to understand why a former president whose daughter is kidnapped by terrorists might want to organize his own unauthorized paramilitary force to rescue her. But try explaining it to the current president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: For Netanyahu, like Trump, Only ‘Fraud’ Can Explain His Defeat
description: Israel’s democratic transition is set for Sunday, but nothing is certain amid the prime minister’s scorched-earth campaign to wreck his opponents’ coalition.
content: TEL AVIV — For Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel is witnessing “the greatest election fraud in the history of the country.” For Donald Trump, defeat last November was “the crime of the century.” The two men’s language overlaps, it seems, because their overwhelming sense of invincibility is confounded by democratic process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Shashank Bengali
title: Bring the sushi bar home: A Japanese chain rents conveyor belts for takeout.
description: To survive a prolonged state of emergency, restaurants in Japan are getting creative.
content: As parts of Japan endure a prolonged state of emergency to battle the latest coronavirus surge, one restaurant chain came up with a way to replicate the sushi bar experience at home: renting out conveyor belts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Farewell, Millennial Lifestyle Subsidy
description: The price for Ubers, scooters and Airbnb rentals is going up as tech companies aim for profitability.
content: A few years ago, while on a work trip in Los Angeles, I hailed an Uber for a crosstown ride during rush hour. I knew it would be a long trip, and I steeled myself to fork over $60 or $70.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jamila Michener
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jamila Michener. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jamila Michener. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Negroni
title: R.V. Life Means Never Having to Leave Home (or the Office)
description: Ownership of recreational vehicles is on the rise and with improved technology, an attractive lure for those who can hit the road to travel, or work, wherever they choose.
content: This article is part of our new series, Currents, which examines how rapid advances in technology are transforming our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: Pilots in India plead for better compensation for colleagues who died of Covid.
description: Air India pilots had their salaries reduced during the pandemic, a union says, and many came to India’s aid when people and vaccines needed to be transported, though they were not vaccinated themselves.
content: NEW DELHI — Amitesh Prasad, a pilot with Air India, came down with Covid-like symptoms in April this year after he flew from San Francisco to the southern Indian city of Bengaluru. He was among the many pilots who had worked on one of India’s largest humanitarian missions to bring home stranded residents and transport essential pandemic-related supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Denver’s Nikola Jokic Wins N.B.A.’s Most Valuable Player Award
description: Jokic set career highs in points, rebounds and assists, and kept the Nuggets afloat after Jamal Murray, their second-leading scorer, went down with a knee injury.
content: Nikola Jokic was an afterthought in 2014. A pudgy center from Serbia, he was a role player for a club in the Adriatic League when the Denver Nuggets took a low-risk gamble in the second round of the N.B.A. draft and selected him with the 41st pick — then promptly stashed him in Europe for another season. There was no guarantee that he would ever appear in an N.B.A. uniform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Zachary Small
title: Museum’s Role in Police Mural Outside Detroit Draws Criticism
description: The Detroit Institute of Arts sponsored the mural as part of its efforts to support art in the communities it serves, but critics say the “pro-police” art work sends the wrong message.
content: They unveiled the mural outside the Sterling Heights police station with fanfare on June 1. The mayor of the city in the Detroit suburbs cut the red ribbon to mark the installation of the artwork, which had been three years in the making and depicts police officers bowing their heads and clasping hands in front of an American flag.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who is Hacking the U.S. Economy?
description: In the past few weeks, cyberattacks have taken major industries hostage. Who are the perpetrators and why are the infiltrations becoming so common?
content: In the past few weeks, some of the biggest industries in the U.S. have been held up by cyberattacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Republican Filibuster Blocks Pay Equity Bill in the Senate
description: In a vote choreographed to fail, Democrats tried to bring to the Senate floor a bill to make it easier to sue over compensation discrimination, hoping to make the case to end the filibuster.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Tuesday blocked debate on a bill to combat pay discrimination against women and L.G.B.T.Q. workers, the first in a series of votes set up by Democratic leaders this month to highlight the power of the filibuster to stop even the consideration of legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Cottrell
title: Alex DiFrancesco Captures the Fraught Magic of the In-Between
description: The story collection “Transmutation” follows protagonists across the gender spectrum filling their days with TV, Twitter and revenge.
content: TRANSMUTATION Stories By Alex DiFrancesco
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: Was This Picasso Lost Because of the Nazis? Heirs and Bavaria Disagree.
description: Officials have refused to refer a dispute over the work held by the state painting collections to a national commission created to review claims of art lost in the Nazi era.
content: BERLIN — Almost two decades ago, Germany established a national commission to address disputes over art looted or sold in the Nazi era. While the opinions of the advisory commission are not binding, its recommendations have been routinely followed and about 20 artworks have been returned to the heirs of people who suffered because of the Third Reich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Fremson
title: Protected Habitat, for a Population of One
description: Fifty years ago, Marty Bluewater fought to keep his home among the nesting birds of Protection Island. Now he’s fighting for the birds.
content: PROTECTION ISLAND, Wash. — From their perch atop a dead tree on the edge of a cliff, a pair of bald eagles enjoyed a panoramic view of a small island in the Strait of Juan de Fuca, off the coast of Washington State. Far below, seated on a bench surrounded by tall, swaying grasses, the island’s lone human resident, Marty Bluewater, watched them through binoculars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Hubbard
title: How to Keep the Economy Booming — And Meet the Demand for Workers
description: Rising demand must be met by rising supply.
content: In recent economic news, optimists and pessimists could both find evidence to support their outlooks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Parker
title: How to Prep Your Relationship for Post-Pandemic Life
description: Experts share tips on how couples can adjust to spending time apart again.
content: Remember how strange it was to be alone at home with your significant other 24/7 after the coronavirus first surfaced? Or how uncomfortable it was to get to know a new romantic partner with a mask on in what felt like a vacuum?
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy Visual Books, From Queer Love to the Soul of a Nation
description: A selection of recent visual books of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: KAWS: What Party, by Brooklyn Museum. (Phaidon, $59.95.) With essays by the critic Daniel Birnbaum and the Brooklyn Museum curator Eugenie Tsai, this monograph provides a comprehensive overview of the artist’s genre-crossing, Pop Art-inspired work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Man Slaps Macron During Visit to Southern France
description: Two people were arrested after a man slapped the French president as he was approaching a small crowd, prompting condemnation of the attack across the political spectrum.
content: PARIS — A man slapped President Emmanuel Macron of France in the face on Tuesday during a visit by the French leader to the southeast of the country, prompting swift political condemnation as a video of the incident spread rapidly on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Robert Hollander, Who Led Readers Into ‘The Inferno,’ Dies at 87
description: He and his wife wrote an admired translation of Dante’s “Divine Comedy,” and he began an innovative project to digitize centuries of scholarly commentary.
content: Robert Hollander was the sort of literature professor to recommend “years of rereading” to understand a great book. To study his own favorite masterpiece, Dante Alighieri’s “The Divine Comedy,” Professor Hollander held himself to a yet higher standard. He mastered seven centuries of line-by-line commentary about the poem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Young Creators Are Burning Out and Breaking Down
description: Many people who have found fame on TikTok are struggling with mental health issues.
content: Lately, it’s been hard for Jack Innanen, a 22-year-old TikTok star from Toronto, to create content. “I feel like I’m tapping a keg that’s been empty for a year,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: London Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Rape and Kidnap of Sarah Everard
description: Wayne Couzens admitted to charges of rape and kidnapping of the 33-year-old marketing executive, whose killing in March touched off national anger at male violence against women.
content: LONDON — A police officer has pleaded guilty to the rape and kidnapping of Sarah Everard, the British woman whose killing in March touched off a national reckoning over male violence against women.
source.name: The New York Times

title: They wanted to help their college-age children, but wound up buried in debt.
description: Parent PLUS loans are underwritten by the federal government and have become popular with parents who want to borrow to help pay for their children’s education. Many parents have turned to such loans as college costs have rocketed past wage growth, researchers say.
content: Parent PLUS loans are underwritten by the federal government and have become popular with parents who want to borrow to help pay for their children’s education. Many parents have turned to such loans as college costs have rocketed past wage growth, researchers say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Just Visited the Solar System’s Biggest Moon
description: The Juno spacecraft completed a close flyby of Ganymede, Jupiter’s biggest moon, as it transitions into a new phase of its mission.
content: Time for your close-up, Ganymede.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: In a Different Capitol Siege, Republicans in Oregon Call for Accountability
description: G.O.P. lawmakers in the state are calling for the resignation of a legislator who appears to have encouraged protesters to breach the State Capitol in December.
content: A little more than two weeks before a mob of supporters of Donald J. Trump stormed the U.S. Capitol, falsely claiming that he had won the election, a strikingly similar event had unfolded on the other side of the country, at the State Capitol in Oregon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: For Chloe Flower, the Décor Always Serves the Music
description: With a few exceptions, the composer and social media influencer’s walls are bare. But who needs art when you have Liberace’s piano?
content: The test of a first-rate intelligence, F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, is the ability to hold two opposing ideas in mind at the same time while still managing to function.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $1.95 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: El Chapo’s Wife Set to Plead Guilty to Helping Run Drug Empire
description: Emma Coronel Aispuro is scheduled to appear in court in Washington on Thursday to admit her role in her husband’s criminal activities.
content: Emma Coronel Aispuro, the wife of the notorious Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, is set to plead guilty this week to charges of helping her husband run his multibillion-dollar empire and then, after one of his arrests, escape in dramatic fashion from a high-security Mexican prison, according to a person familiar with the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Nicholas Fandos
title: Senate Report Details Security Failures in Jan. 6 Capitol Riot
description: A 127-page joint report is the most comprehensive and detailed account to date on the intelligence, communications and policing failures around the Capitol riot.
content: WASHINGTON — Top federal intelligence agencies failed to adequately warn law enforcement officials before the Jan. 6 riot that pro-Trump extremists were threatening violence, including plans to “storm the Capitol,” infiltrate its tunnel system and “bring guns,” according to a new report by two Senate committees that outlines large-scale failures that contributed to the deadly assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Unloved by Generations of Soldiers, the M.R.E. Finds a Fan Base
description: The rations often derided as ‘Meals, Rarely Edible’ have gotten (somewhat) better and become objects of fascination for millions of civilians.
content: Kathleen Ehl had always thought of her business as a niche affair — an online store called North Georgia Outdoors Supply that she and her husband run out of their home in Gainesville, selling Meals, Ready-to-Eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Michael Che’s New York State of Mind
description: The “Saturday Night Live” comedian talks about “Illmatic” by Nas, Richard Pryor’s stand-up and the importance of a fresh haircut.
content: Michael Che was trying to relax — really, he was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Greenwood
title: ‘For Those I Love’ Sets Sad Stories to Electronic Beats
description: David Balfe never thought the public would hear his deeply personal debut album. But it became a runaway success in his native Ireland.
content: David Balfe feels guilty. The Irish musician’s debut album “For Those I Love,” which he recorded under the same name, has had the kind of success most artists only dream of: It has won widespread critical praise and was only beaten to the No. 1 spot in the Irish album charts by Justin Bieber.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Gose
title: Investors Fret as Biden Takes Aim at a 100-Year-Old Tax Loophole
description: The administration wants to rein in a tax deferral on gains from the sale of real estate. Opponents worry that the move would stifle investment.
content: As a real estate investor, Michael Clarke has learned how to roll earnings from the sale of one property into the purchase of another to save on his tax bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Employers Are Begging for Workers. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
description: The political scientist Jamila Michener discusses employer panic, America’s poverty addiction and the messy politics of work.
content: There has been a bit of panic lately over employers who say not enough people want to apply for open jobs. Are we facing a labor shortage? Have stimulus checks and expanded unemployment insurance payments created an economy full of people who don’t want to work — and who are holding back the economic recovery? That’s one theory, anyway. But it’s leading to real policy change: 25 Republican governors have cut off expanded unemployment benefits early.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Pete Kiehart
title: A Very Strange Version of the Paris Night
description: The pandemic may be ebbing, but Paris still has a curfew, which feels completely unnatural in the City of Light.
content: PARIS — It happens every night, and yet it feels so strange each time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Is Tickled by Trump’s Pants
description: “You know, usually if you got this close to Trump’s crotch, he’d pay you $130,000,” Jimmy Kimmel joked of rumors that the former president had worn his pants backward.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: MoviePass Deceived Users So They’d Use It Less, F.T.C. Says
description: Federal regulators detailed tactics the company, which settled accusations against it, used to try to make its most active users go to the movies less.
content: MoviePass, the failed subscription service that promised unlimited moviegoing for $9.95 a month, agreed on Monday to settle Federal Trade Commission accusations that it knowingly deceived customers, making the service difficult to use, and exposed their personal data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Biden’s first two judicial nominees are confirmed with modest Republican support.
description: Senate Democrats intend to sprint to fill scores of federal vacancies and rebalance the ideological makeup of the courts after the Trump era.
content: The Senate confirmed President Biden’s first two judicial nominees on Tuesday with modest Republican support, the start of what Democrats intend to be a sprint to fill scores of federal vacancies and rebalance the ideological makeup of the courts after the Trump era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Brad Lander for Comptroller
description: The editorial board endorses Brad Lander for New York City comptroller.
content: The New York City comptroller serves as the fiscal watchdog, which is serious business in a city with a budget of nearly $99 billion. The office oversees the city’s roughly $240 billion in pension funds, approving its contracts and investigating its agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: States warn J.&J. doses could expire soon and the White House urges them to consult the F.D.A.
description: A White House adviser said governors could consult with the Food and Drug Administration on storage procedures as the agency examines how to possibly extend the shelf life of the vaccine.
content: State health officials are growing increasingly concerned about whether doses of the Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine may expire this month, warning they could go to waste if they go unused in the coming weeks or are not sent elsewhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Pam Belluck
title: Alzheimer’s Drug Is Bonanza for Biogen, Most Likely at Taxpayer Expense
description: Despite scant evidence that it works, the drug, Aduhelm, is predicted to generate billions of dollars in revenue, much of it from Medicare.
content: The Food and Drug Administration’s decision on Monday to approve a new Alzheimer’s medication over the fierce objections of its scientific advisers sets into motion one of the most controversial drug introductions in years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: This article was published in error.
description: This article was published in error.
content: A mock article intended for a testing system was inadvertently published on this page earlier.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A tense summer for Northern Ireland.
content: More than two decades after Northern Ireland’s bloody 30-year guerrilla war, Brexit has inflamed sectarian passions to a degree unseen in years, posing a threat to the 1998 Good Friday Agreement that ended decades of sectarian strife.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to Know About Workplace Mask Rules
description: Tuesday: The state updated its standards for wearing masks at work. Here’s what to know about the changes.
content: Good morning.

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: A U.N. Declaration on Ending AIDS Should Have Been Easy. It Wasn’t.
description: Even with U.N.’s previous goals unmet, delegates tried to water down provisions regarding protections for vulnerable populations and patents for essential drugs.
content: The United Nations on Tuesday adopted new targets for ending AIDS as a public health threat by 2030, seemingly a goal most countries could easily have agreed to. But consensus had been elusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Terry McAuliffe Wins Democratic Nomination for Governor in Virginia
description: Mr. McAuliffe, who previously served as governor, overcame four rivals, benefiting from the support of the party establishment. His victory set up a general election race against a wealthy Republican, Glenn Youngkin.
content: MCLEAN, Va — Former Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe captured the Democratic nomination for his old job on Tuesday, easily dispatching four party rivals to set up an expensive general election that will test how liberal Virginia has become and present the first major referendum at the ballot box on the Democratic Party under President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Trouble in Los Angeles County: Too Many Peacocks
description: Some residents admire their beauty. Others complain about the noise, the aggression and the droppings. Now, officials are considering an ordinance to stop people from feeding peafowl.
content: County officials in Los Angeles have a request: Please don’t feed the peacocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Many People Have a Vivid ‘Mind’s Eye,’ While Others Have None at All
description: Scientists are finding new ways to probe two not-so-rare conditions to better understand the links between vision, perception and memory.
content: Dr. Adam Zeman didn’t give much thought to the mind’s eye until he met someone who didn’t have one. In 2005, the British neurologist saw a patient who said that a minor surgical procedure had taken away his ability to conjure images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Cecilia Kang
title: Ohio’s attorney general wants Google to be declared a public utility.
description: If Google were declared a so-called common carrier like a utility company, it would prevent the company from prioritizing its own products, services and websites in search results.
content: Ohio’s attorney general, Dave Yost, filed a lawsuit on Tuesday in pursuit of a novel effort to have Google declared a public utility and subject to government regulation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Two Days Later, He Moved Into My Loft’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Orphaned at 13, I thought about how I would never again play basketball with my father or talk about crushes on girls with my mother. But even then, living with my grandparents, I didn’t feel those expected activities were suitable for me. As time passed, I discovered who I really am but kept it secret. One family lunch in the Philippines, my aunt casually asked me when I would get a girlfriend in front of my grandfather. I bowed my head in shame. Surprisingly, he was all smiles and ready to hug me. His gay grandson is free, finally. — John Lorenz Santos
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: U.N. Security Council Recommends António Guterres for a Second Term
description: The Council’s recommendation basically assures the Portuguese statesman’s tenure as secretary general and extends the history of male-only stewardship of the United Nations since its 1945 founding.
content: The United Nations Security Council on Tuesday formally recommended the re-election of António Guterres as secretary general, assuring a second term for the Portuguese statesman that will keep him in office until 2027.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang, Elian Peltier and Alan Feuer
title: The Criminals Thought the Devices Were Secure. But the Seller Was the F.B.I.
description: Global law enforcement officials revealed a three-year operation in which they said they had intercepted over 20 million messages. Hundreds of arrests were made in more than a dozen countries.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The cellphones, procured on the black market, performed a single function hidden behind a calculator app: sending encrypted messages and photos.

author: By Ian Parkes
title: Lewis Hamilton Gives Encouragement to Naomi Osaka
description: Hamilton, the F1 champion, says he knows how it feels to be under intense media scrutiny and supports Osaka’s stand against news conferences.
content: The tennis player Naomi Osaka can add Lewis Hamilton, the Formula 1 champion, to her list of supporters.

author: By Martin Heinrich
title: Your Next Car and Clothes Dryer Could Help Save Our Planet
description: To slow global warming, we need to electrify vast parts of our economy and power it with clean energy.
content: Our future depends on our acting now to confront the climate crisis by enacting policies to convert our economy from fossil fuels to clean energy. By making this switch, we will also create millions of new jobs, save American households money on their energy bills and protect lives by improving the air we breathe in our homes and workplaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 French Open: What to Watch on Tuesday
description: Stefanos Tsitsipas and Daniil Medvedev will clash as the quarterfinal matches begin at Roland Garros.

title: Wealthiest Executives Paid Little to Nothing in Federal Income Taxes, Report Says
description: An analysis by ProPublica based on I.R.S. documents showed billionaires like Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk benefited from tax code loopholes and a focus on taxing income over wealth.
content: WASHINGTON — The 25 richest Americans, including Jeff Bezos, Michael Bloomberg and Elon Musk, paid relatively little — and sometimes nothing — in federal income taxes between 2014 and 2018, according to an analysis from the news organization ProPublica that was based on a trove of Internal Revenue Service tax data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Paula Badosa’s Body Was Ready to Win, but Her Mind Was Not
description: The Spanish player is yet another in the sport who has battled depression and spoken openly about it.
content: PARIS — For Paula Badosa, the winning and accompanying expectations came far too quickly, as they often do for women in tennis, with some pretty terrible effects.

title: Nets Brush Aside the Bucks to Lead Series, 2-0
description: A 39-point drubbing sends the series back to Milwaukee, and the Bucks back to the drawing board.
content: One can easily call the Milwaukee Bucks’ performance against the Nets on Monday night an embarrassment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Colonial Pipeline chief says an oversight let hackers into its system.
description: Cybercriminals gained access via an old virtual private network, allowing them to paralyze a critical U.S. fuel artery.
content: The top executive of the Colonial Pipeline told a Senate committee on Tuesday that an oversight appears to have allowed hackers into its computer systems and contributed to the paralyzing of the delivery of gasoline and other fuels up and down the East Coast.

description: The proceeds from Stuart Weitzman’s “Inverted Jennies,” a 1933 gold piece known as the double eagle and the One-Cent Magenta stamp will go to charitable ventures.
content: The “Inverted Jenny,” the postage stamp famously misprinted with an airplane upside down, climbed to a new height on Tuesday when a block of four sold for $4.9 million, a record for a United States stamp at auction and $2 million more than its last reported sale price.

author: By David Leonhardt
title: An Investment With a Big Return

content: How has the Senate managed to find a rare area of bipartisan agreement and put together a major bill to finance technology and manufacturing? A brief bit of history helps answer that question.

description: Anne Sebba’s new biography tells the story of a fanatical Communist and loving mother who went to her death proclaiming her innocence.

title: In Quantum Physics, Everything Is Relative
description: Carlo Rovelli’s “Helgoland” explores the world of the smallest particles and asks what makes them unique.
content: HELGOLANDMaking Sense of the Quantum RevolutionBy Carlo RovelliTranslated by Erica Segre and Simon Carnell

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Everyone Has a Theory About Shopping Carts
description: An essential tool. An inspiration for artists. A public nuisance. The humble shopping cart has been all of these in the decades since it was invented. But what does it reveal about our character?
content: The next time you go to the grocery store, consider the ordinary shopping cart as something more than a rattling basket blocking your parking space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Atinuke
title: Erin Entrada Kelly Draws (Literally) From Her Life in a New Illustrated Middle Grade Series
description: A Filipino American girl who’s afraid of falling tackles the tree in her new backyard in “Maybe Maybe Marisol Rainey.”
content: MAYBE MAYBE MARISOL RAINEYBy Erin Entrada Kelly
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Bruised by the Pandemic, Carnegie Hall Plans a Comeback
description: New York’s premier concert hall hopes a star-studded season will draw virus-wary fans. But there’s still uncertainty.
content: For 15 months, Carnegie Hall’s doors have been closed to the public by the coronavirus pandemic. Hundreds of performances have been canceled at the hall — one of the world’s most renowned concert spaces — and millions of dollars in ticket sales lost. Facing a financial crisis, Carnegie reduced its staff by nearly half and dipped into its endowment to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Douglas Cramer, Producer of TV Hits and Art Aficionado, Dies at 89
description: He had a hand in some of the biggest shows of the 20th century, including “Dynasty” and “The Love Boat.”
content: Douglas S. Cramer, who produced some of the most successful television shows of the 20th century, many — including “The Love Boat” and “Dynasty” — in partnership with Aaron Spelling, and who used his substantial wealth to become a leading art collector, died on Friday at his home on Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: Sarah Feinberg Chosen to Lead M.T.A.; Would Be First Woman in Role
description: Governor Andrew M. Cuomo will nominate Sarah Feinberg, a close ally, to oversee the largest transit system in North America.
content: Sarah Feinberg will be nominated to become the first woman to lead the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the largest public transit system in North America, responsible for running New York City’s subway, buses and two commuter train lines, transit officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Legacy Russell Is Named Next Leader of the Kitchen
description: Currently the associate curator of exhibitions at the Studio Museum in Harlem, she takes over in September from Tim Griffin as executive director and chief curator.
content: The Kitchen, the nonprofit arts space in Chelsea, celebrates its 50th anniversary this year. Its timeline doubles as a history of downtown experimentalism: it has helped reveal artists like Laurie Anderson and Simone Leigh, while consistently privileging research practices, adventurous formats and cross-disciplinary exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Reese
title: New Audiobooks From Seth Rogen, Danielle Henderson and Elon Green
description: From a grisly ’90s true-crime story to slapstick comedy to family heartbreak, these narrators know how to keep your attention.
content: The only thing more essential to a road trip than an audiobook is gas. I often spend as much time selecting the listening material for a long drive as I do mapping the itinerary, and I’ve seldom made a better choice than LAST CALL: A TRUE STORY OF LOVE, LUST, AND MURDER IN QUEER NEW YORK (Macmillan Audio, 8 hours, 11 minutes), by Elon Green. Recently, my husband and I listened to this true-crime stunner on a drive from North Carolina to New York, and the hours flew by as quickly as the landscape. In 1991, a Pennsylvania Turnpike maintenance worker opened an unusually heavy trash bag and found a mutilated body: “It looked like a loaf of bread,” he recalls, “but then I saw freckles.” The freckles belonged to a gay man, a divorced banker and father who’d last been seen at a Midtown Manhattan piano bar called the Townhouse. Just over a year later, workers emptying trash cans at a rest stop in New Jersey found a bloody bag containing a human head. It belonged to a closeted gay man, a married father of four who had also last been seen at the Townhouse. These were the first known victims of the so-called Last Call Killer, who went on to murder at least two more gay men the next year. The nearly decade-long and sometimes bungled hunt for the serial murderer gives the book its suspense. Green’s sensitive portraits of the victims, and his deeply researched re-creation of an epoch of gay history, provide its soul. Inherently shocking material needs no dramatization, and David Pittu’s understated narration highlights the tragedy and horror of these crimes. “Last Call” is the kind of book that keeps you wide awake all night turning the pages. As an audiobook, it will keep you wide awake all day as you drive, hoping you don’t get wherever you’re going before it ends.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A new drug could drive up insurance prices and earn billions from Medicare.
description: A new Alzheimer’s medication is likely to further inflate high U.S. health care costs even as it is poised to be a blockbuster for Biogen, its manufacturer.
content: A new Alzheimer’s medication is likely to further inflate high U.S. health care costs even as it is poised to be a blockbuster for Biogen, its manufacturer.

title: Bill Bratton Explains His Ideas of Good Policing
description: In “The Profession,” Bratton, with his co-author, Peter Knobler, offers an engaging account of his half-century in law enforcement.

description: While the world trained its epidemiological attention on the coronavirus last year, another pandemic virus infected 1.5 million people and killed 690,000.

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Kamala Harris, With Blunt Language on Border, Forges Immigration Image
description: The vice president concluded her first trip abroad, a high-stakes trip to Mexico and Guatemala during which she took on the politically volatile issue.
content: MEXICO CITY — Before flying to Guatemala and Mexico on her first foreign trip, Vice President Kamala Harris faced questions over how she would approach her role as the face of President Biden’s plan to bolster the region and deter migration to the United States.

title: Meet the Pandemic’s Newest Doctors, Who Quickly Became Pros
description: In “Life on the Line,” Emma Goldberg takes readers behind the hospital curtains in New York City at the peak of the pandemic.

author: By Eric Ducker
title: Meditation Apps Want Us to Chill Out. Musicians Are Happy to Help.
description: Music and mindfulness have become increasingly linked during the pandemic, and artists like Erykah Badu, Grimes and Arcade Fire are teaming with tech companies to make it happen.
content: When Erykah Badu creates a new song, she begins with instruments that are usually treated as accessories, like singing bells, shakers, mallets and tuning forks. It’s been that way since “Baduizm,” the vocalist and producer’s 1997 debut.

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 French Open: What to Watch on Wednesday
description: Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Iga Swiatek all feature on the second day of quarterfinals at Roland Garros.

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Matthew Goldstein
title: Electric truck start-up Lordstown doesn’t have cash to begin production.
description: Lordstown Motors, which bought a shuttered General Motors factory in Ohio, warned that it needs to raise more money and might not survive.
content: Lordstown Motors, an electric vehicle start-up that aimed to revive a shuttered General Motors factory in Ohio, said on Tuesday that it did not have enough cash to start commercial production of its electric pickup truck and might have to close its doors.

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Washington State allows for free marijuana joints with Covid-19 vaccine.
description: The promotion, called “Joints for Jabs,” is one of many across the United States whose aim is to get more Americans vaccinated.
content: As part of its strategy to vaccinate more of its population, Washington State will allow adults to claim a free marijuana joint when they receive a Covid-19 vaccination shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Knowlton
title: Two Books on the Bizarreness of Texas
description: “Forget the Alamo,” by Bryan Burrough, Chris Tomlinson and Jason Stanford, and “A Single Star and Bloody Knuckles,” by Bill Minutaglio, have many strange stories to tell about the Lone Star State.
content: FORGET THE ALAMOThe Rise and Fall of an American MythBy Bryan Burrough, Chris Tomlinson and Jason StanfordA SINGLE STAR AND BLOODY KNUCKLESA History of Politics and Race in TexasBy Bill Minutaglio

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Is Trying to Tame Inflation. It Matters to Much of the Globe.
description: Rising costs at its factories — an accelerating trend, new data showed — could trickle into the rest of the world economy.
content: SHANGHAI — Prices are jumping in the United States and around the world, prompting growing warnings that a wave of inflation could threaten the global economy if it persists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Adam Satariano
title: A widespread internet outage affects major websites.
description: The sites of the British government, The New York Times and Twitter were among those that were briefly inaccessible for some users.
content: Several major websites, including those of the British government, The New York Times, CNN, The Financial Times and The Guardian, were briefly inaccessible for many users on Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: In the U.S., vaccines for the youngest are expected this fall.
description: Pfizer and Moderna are testing their vaccines in children under 12, and are expected to have results in hand by the end of the summer.
content: Coronavirus vaccines may be available in the fall for U.S. children as young as 6 months, drugmakers say. Pfizer and Moderna are testing their vaccines in children under 12 years, and are expected to have results in hand for children aged 5 through 11 by September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Protesters in Minnesota Block Pipeline Construction
description: Activists blockaded an Enbridge Energy construction site in Minnesota on Monday, attempting to halt the building of a $9 billion pipeline that would carry oil through the state’s delicate watersheds and tribal lands.

title: Corrections: June 8, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 8, 2021.
content: An article on June 1 about heat deaths linked to climate change misstated in one instance the scope of the increase in deaths. The study found that an average of 37 percent of the heat-related deaths in warm seasons could be linked to climate change, not that climate change had boosted heat deaths by 37 percent.
source.name: The New York Times
